In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can define a function `clean_column` that will do the desired cleaning of column names as follows:

```julia
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
    return lowercase(replace(col, r"\s+" => "_"))
end
```

This function uses Julia's built-in `lowercase` and `replace` functions to lowercase the column name and replace any whitespace with an underscore. The regular expression `r"\s+"` matches one or more whitespace characters, which includes spaces, tabs, and newlines.

You can use this function as follows:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"
```

If you want to strip leading and trailing whitespaces as well, you can modify the function like this:

```julia
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
    return lowercase(replace(strip(col), r"\s+" => "_"))
end
```

The `strip` function removes leading and trailing whitespace from a string. Note that in this case, the `replace` function is applied after the `strip` to ensure that any internal spaces are still replaced with underscores.
